text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with perfect potato salad that's
right i'm going to show you what i think
is the best way to make perfect potato
salad which by the way should not be
confused with the perfect way to make
the best potato salad since who even
knows what that means so what I'm hoping
to do here is just simply show you the
best methods and practices and possibly
techniques for making a potato salad
that's going to be perfect and by
perfect of course we mean perfect for
you so with that let's go ahead and get
started with the first huge tip and that
would be to boil the potatoes whole with
the skin on and for me the best choice
is for very large russet potatoes these
are roughly about 12 ounces each and
since we are gonna cook these whole it's
very important to try to get ones into
the same size okay so ignore those dirty
looks at the market I want you to go
through that whole bin and find four
potatoes that are the same weight in
shape and then above-and-beyond
selection another super important factor
here is that we cook these in heavily
salted water yes that heavily salted so
believe it or not that was a quarter cup
of kosher salt which may look like a
crazy amount but that really is how much
we need and then what we'll do is go
ahead and cover these in some nice fresh
cold water and yes in case you're
wondering this techniques gonna work
with any variety of potato it just won't
be as good okay when I'm making a salad
I want a potato that has a starchy
absorbent texture and not something
that's firm and waxy so that's why the
rest is my top choice followed by a gues
Yukon Gold but anyway no matter what
you're using what we'll do is bring that
up to a boil over high heat
at which point we'll reduce our heat to
medium-low to maintain a nice steady
simmer and then all we're gonna do is
simply cook those potatoes until they're
tender which I believe took me about 40
minutes or so but of course that's going
to depend on the size so instead of
going by time what we'll do is test
these and for this I'll use this metal
skier and we'll test those by giving
them the old poka poka and I'm happy to
report mine were perfect not firm not
soft and mushy but just perfectly tender
and then what we're going to do once
we've determined our potatoes have
cooked long enough is go ahead and
transfer those to plates because the
next step may be the most important and
that's letting these cool down to room
temp before we work with them alright we
never want to dress hot potatoes with a
mayonnaise-based dressing since we may
end up with something a little
greasy and unappetizing having said that
working with cold refrigerated potatoes
isn't great either so letting these cool
down to room temp is ideal so we'll
simply move those off the stove and
maybe in front of an open window and
we'll let those cool completely and
while we're waiting is probably a good
idea to go ahead and mix up our dressing
which as I mentioned and as you can see
is mayonnaise based in real mayonnaise
please I mean you can use fat-free
mayonnaise just not for a potato salad
and then to that we will add some apple
cider vinegar or of course the vinegar
of your choice
and then we'll also toss in a couple
spoons of mustard I'm going with Dijon
but just some good old-fashioned
American yellow mustard will work and
then we will finish this up by seasoning
with some salt as well as some freshly
ground black pepper and then last but
not least a little bit of cayenne and
that's gonna be it for this very simple
dressing we'll go ahead and grab our
whisk and give that a mix and as soon as
that's all combined it's ready to use
with our potatoes assuming that they're
room temp okay if you only remember one
thing from this video besides cooking
the potatoes whole with a lot of salt
it's that we don't want to use this
dressing on the potatoes if they're
still warm or hot so if you happen to
finish this dressing and your potatoes
are still cooling just simply transfer
it into the fridge and then what we'll
do once our potatoes our room temp is
peel them by simply scraping off the
skin which is not only going to be
really easy we're also gonna waste like
zero amount of potato and then just one
little heads up since we did cook these
with the skin on
there's gonna be a little bit of
discoloration under the skin which
really affects nothing it's just an
appearance thing so once we've removed
the skin if there's a few dark spots you
want to scrape off or a couple little
eyes or whatever to clean up go ahead
and then what we'll do once these are
peeled is cut them up into pieces
roughly three times the size that we
want the pieces of potato in our cell to
be at the end and that might have been
confusing so let me say that again and
hopefully a less confusing way since
these potatoes are gonna break up as we
mix our salad together I don't like to
start off by cutting these up too small
all right so my theory is whatever size
we cut them up at this point they're
gonna be like a third or a quarter of
this size by the time the cell is done
and yes it absolutely helps if you throw
your pinky out while you're doing this
it acts as a counterbalance and also
looks quite elegant
and then once our potatoes are cut we'll
transfer those into a large mixing bowl
at which way we can proceed to final
assembly again assuming that these are
room temp and if they're not let them
cool more but mine we're good
so I'm gonna proceed with the rest of
the ingredients which for me is gonna
start with a little touch of finely
diced sweet onion and by the way onion
is a controversial ingredient so I'm
going to spend an entire paragraph about
that in the blog post so the onions
optional but the rest of these
ingredients are not so we're definitely
gonna want to toss in some diced celery
as well as some freshly chopped to tell
you parsley and then we'll also toss in
some chopped hard-boiled egg which I
will not be chopping up but rather using
one of these slicers so we'll slice it
one way and then the other and I guess
if you wanted you could turn it on
inside and cut it a third time
but I don't because just like the potato
these are gonna break up as we mix
speaking of which once we've added the
last of our ingredients I like to take a
big spoon and give this a mix before I
add the dressing which should be
completely honest maybe an unnecessary
step all right I really don't know if
this comes out any better than if we had
just thrown the dressing in now but none
of that matters to me because it feels
right and above and beyond giving these
ingredients a little bit of a head start
getting combined I'm also able to start
breaking up these potatoes without being
distracted by the dressing
okay so we'll give that a quick stir
kind of breaking up those bigger pieces
of potato as we do at which point
finally we can add our dressing and
continue mixing oh and by the way if you
happen to be thinking to yourself as
soon as this is mixed up I bet we can
eat well no I have some very
disappointing news unfortunately there's
no way to properly finish seasoning this
and check in the texture until it's
thoroughly thoroughly chilled so go
ahead and taste it if you want but we're
just not going to get an accurate
reading if this is room temp so what
we'll do after we mix that up is cover
it with some plastic and transfer it in
the fridge for at least two or three
hours or until thoroughly chilled so
that's what I did and a few hours later
it might look like this speaking of
which this always looks terrible until
you mix it up again so relax it gets
better and what we'll do is grab a fork
and give it a taste
and we're checking for two things does
it need more salt which it always does
so I'm going to toss them in and then
also we're determining does it need a
little more Maine
so if it seems a little bit dry I like
to throw another spoon in which I almost
always do and then we'll go ahead and
give that a mix and we'll give it one
final taste and one thing I should have
mentioned by now because this video is
mostly focusing on techniques and
methods don't think you have to use all
the ingredients I used or only the
ingredients I used okay as long as you
use the proper techniques you can add
anything you want to this you know
things like pickles & peppers stuff like
that okay so when it comes to the
ingredients it's up to you to determine
what makes your potato salad valid and
if you like it pretty much anything goes
but anyway once that's all set we'll go
ahead and transfer that into something
slightly more attractive and maybe
finished with a little bit of fresh
chive and then because every potato
salad I ever made in every cafeteria and
deli ever worked was always garnished
with a little bit of paprika on top I'm
gonna do the same except with cayenne
and that's it that is now officially
ready to enjoy your picnic or cookout
except I don't have one of those under
schedule so I'm just gonna eat mine
standing in the kitchen which is fine
and of course normally at this point I
would brag about how good it tastes well
like I said this was just outlined the
method and I'm not exactly sure what
you're gonna put in yours but have you
said that if you do use the same
ingredients this comes out really good
and for me is like the epitome of a
classic American potato salad which I
learned from my mother Pauline makes you
rest in peace
which reminds me if you're one of these
superfans working on a trivia game
potato salad is the first food I can
remember eating apparently it was one of
my favorite and first baby foods so
whether you have a picnic coming up or
maybe just some hungry babies around I
really do hope you give this a try soon
